slides.title: Analytics Made Simple
slides.narration: Analytics can feel overwhelming. Hundreds of numbers, charts everywhere. But only a few metrics actually matter for your business. Let's focus on those.

slides.title: Key Metrics
slides.narration: Four categories that matter. Visibility: are people seeing you? Engagement: are they interested enough to interact? Conversion: are they taking action—calling, booking, buying? Retention: are they coming back? Master these four and you understand your business.

slides.title: Visibility Metrics

content.benchmark: Look for growth week over week

slides.narration: Visibility metrics show how many people see you. Profile views on directories. Search impressions on Google. Website visits. Social media reach. You want these growing week over week. If they're flat or declining, you need more content or promotion.

slides.title: Engagement Metrics

content.benchmark: CTR above 2% is good, above 5% is great

slides.narration: Engagement metrics show if people are interested. Click-through rate on listings and emails. Time on your website. Social interactions like likes and comments. Email open rates. Click-through rate above two percent is good, above five percent is great.

slides.title: Conversion Metrics

content.benchmark: Track cost per conversion to measure ROI

slides.narration: Conversion metrics are the bottom line. Calls and messages received. Bookings and appointments made. Quote requests submitted. Purchases completed. Track cost per conversion to measure your ROI—how much does it cost to get each customer action?

slides.title: Reading Your Dashboard
slides.narration: Your weekly analytics check. Compare this week to last week—are you up or down? Look for patterns—which days perform best? Note what changed—did you do something different? Identify what to test—based on patterns, what could improve results?

slides.title: Pro Tips

tips: Check weekly, not daily (noise vs trends)
Focus on 3-5 key metrics, not everything

slides.narration: Analytics pro tips. Check weekly, not daily—daily is noise, weekly shows trends. Focus on three to five key metrics, not everything available. Set specific goals for each metric. Export monthly reports for your records and to spot long-term trends.

slides.title: Check Your Analytics
slides.narration: Ready to understand your numbers? View your analytics now and practice reading the dashboard. Or set up a weekly report to get key metrics emailed automatically. Data-driven decisions start here.
